item.title: vision
item.description: The Vision of Pubky: Decentralizing Our Future Imagine a future where our online relationships are no longer dictated by corporate giants or state-controlled systems, where you ...

item.title: index
item.description: Welcome to the Pubky Knowledge Base This is a knowledge base for the Pubky platform, which includes Pubky Core, PKARR and Pubky App. These documents are a work in progress, much like Pubky‚Äôs protocols and applications! What is Pubky? Pubky attempts to unlock the web by realizing our vision for a key-based, self-regulating web that puts users in control.

item.title: ELI5
item.description: ELI5: Pubky App Imagine you‚Äôre at a massive party where everyone is sharing stories, showing pictures, and having interesting conversations. You get to decide who you talk to and what stories you listen to.

item.title: Introduction
item.description: Synonym will be initially hosting: Data stores and Pubky App Overview Pubky-app‚Äôs initial focus is building a decentralized social media protocol. Key aspects Data Ownership: Users have full autonomy over their data, hosting it on independent data stores that are decentralized and distributed across the network.

item.title: Homeservers
item.description: The Pubky network allows multiple, independent data stores, known as ‚Äúhomeservers.‚Äù This improves censorship-resistance and prevents any single entity from controlling the ...

item.title: Introduction
item.description: Pubky Core Overview Pubky Core is built on a few core concepts: Data Stores - Decentralized data storage nodes that host user data. Data is encrypted at rest.

item.title: 0.Introduction
item.description: Public-Key Addressable Resource Records Pkarr is a revolutionary system that bridges the gap between the Domain Name System (DNS) and peer-to-peer overlay networks ...

item.title: 1.Why Pkarr?
item.description: This note explores the motivation behind Pkarr, addressing the challenges of distributed semantics, databases, and discovery. In pursuit of a sovereign, distributed, and open web, we identify three challenges: Distributed Semantics Everything expressed as keys and metadata Developing interoperable semantics for verifiable metadata about a set of public-keys that form a digital identity, complete with reputation, social graph, credentials, and more.
